description:
Hermann Köhl (1888 - 1938) was the first aviator to fly across the Atlantic from east to west, i.e. from Europe to North America (accomplished in 1927). This game celebrates that feat. The track is 50 spaces long, tracing Köhl's route, from Germany to North America and back home again.

The game is not very novel in the game-play. Roll a die and move along the track. Obey instructions when you land on a special square. Very nice illustrations illuminate these special points along the track.

First to get to the end, wins.

There are 3x3 grid game board and 2 types of game-pieces red cylinders and yellow cubes. Players draws a cards where are tasks how do position the game-pieces.

At the beginning of each round the board is empty.
Each player draws a card of his objective and in his turn player places or swaps the game-pieces.

The goal of the game, is to achieve the placement showed on the card, either during installation or by swapping two pieces later stage. The player gets a card as a point.

At the end of the game if the deck is exhausted, the player with the most cards is the winner.

Dice based Rugby game, The box folds out into the inside of a rugby stadium, and both players have an elastic band powered catapult they use to "throw" the five dice into the box.

The hope is that the five dice will form a combination of moves resulting in a try.

Most tries, wins

Object of the game is to escape from the aquarium first.

In his turn player draws a card and play a card.
There are usual cards to move his fish to the next available slot
or special cards to exchange his hand, force opponent to discard one card etc.

First fish who has completed his journey to ocean is the winner

1930's party game.

There are 5 large, cardboard horses. Each horse is attached to a length of string. Up to 5 players can play but more can be included if they just bet on the result. Each player with a horse stands about ten feet away from the agreed finish line. Their line of string is attached to something substantial, like a dining room table. At the cry "They're Off!", players jiggle their string and their horse should start to move to towards the finish line. It will get pretty frenetic but that adds to the fun. First owner to get their horse to the finishing line wins.

This is a long-waited sequel game of Manstein: A Brilliant Back-Handed Blow.
The game starts just after the battle of Kursk in Summer 1943 and ends in March 1944.

The game uses the same engine as its predecessor. Each player selects his chits each turn, then draw chits one by one and activate part of the force designated by the chit.
The Soviet player must break the German defense line until the end of the game. The German player must keep the defense line until the end of the game.
The interesting new idea is "no retreat" order by Hitler. There are 6 cities which have no retreat order at the start.  If German player lose one of them while it still has this order, the game immediately ends with Soviet sudden victory. So, German player must defend them or release the order by sacrificing their reinforcement.

Time scale: one month per turn
Map scale: 15-25 km per hex
Unit scale: German divisions; Soviet corps
Counters: 252 1.3cm/0.51 inch
Map: 72 cm x 51 cm
Duration: August 1943 - March 1944 (8 turns)


Issue game of Game Journal  #42

Tessels is a trivia game about homonyms (words with different meanings)
The game consists f 50 cards, each with 3 hints on a homonym.

Players simultaniously try to find the right hymonym. If a player can find the word with only the first hint, he scores 3 points, after the second hint, he gets 2 points and after the 3rd one point.

The first hint is a sentence with the homonym replaced by TESSELS, for example. "While the perents went to a TESSELS, their children played with a TESSELS.

The second hint consists of synonyms for the two meanings (like "orb dance")

And the third hint is a sketch.

Each player has a map overlaid with squares. One player is the Smuggler, the other is a Coastguard. Players start at oppositer ends of the map. Movement is governed by dice. Both players fill in the squares on the path they have taken that throw. Filled-in squares cannot be used again by the player who filled them in.

The objective is to avoid interception or to intercept, depending on which side you are on.

Didactic board game played on a board with the features and markings of hockey on grass, with two smart charts for each team,one dice, 8 sided role and only one piece to move on the board.This feature makes the game very agile and entertaining.
Each team, consisting of one or two people, must follow in the smart chart the current situation of the game according to what the 8-sided dice throw and go placing the piece on the board in the place that corresponds with a indicating the smart chart in use.
The objetc of the game is to lead the team through the smart charts and score a goal.

Dragon Quest: Slime Race is a derby racing game based on the recurring "Slime Races" in the Dragon Quest video game series.

This game uses cards to move the various-colored Slimes around the racetrack. Most cards involve moving a specific Slime a specific number of spaces, but several special cards apply to Slimes in certain race positions (e.g. The Slime in first place may double the distance between it and the Slime in second). Some Slimes have a better set of movement cards than others, and therefore receive lower odds on the betting chart.

Players each get a hand of 7 cards. Depending on what cards a player has, they can form a strategy for which Slimes they think they can push into first and second place at the finish line. The players bet on which Slimes they think will win. Players then take turns playing cards to move the Slimes until there is a first and second place winner. Players tally up their score and advance their score marker. First player to reach 50 points wins the game.

The year is 1941. Within eight months, the United States will join in the war raging in Europe and brewing in the Pacific. However for the moment, the lives of most Americans continue in relative peace...unless you live in the City by the Bay.

In San Francisco crimes, mysteries, and good old-fashioned murder present unique challenges to detectives and residents alike – especially if you happen to be a detective investigating a dirty backroom deal inside a neon lit nightclub, or a future criminal plotting against a spouse under a flickering streetlamp. It is up to you, the players, to create the story.

Ace Detective – which features color and black/white artwork from the grand masters of detective pulp Black Mask Magazine – is a noir storytelling card game that rewards imagination and the turn of a good tale. Play your cards right, tell your story, and be rewarded with the plot points needed to place clues on the suspects of the crime. But be careful as everyone in this gritty city is competing to tell his or her own story...

...to become the true ace detective.

“IN GREAT DEEDS SOMETHING ABIDES. ON GREAT FIELDS SOMETHING STAYS." —Joshua Chamberlain

It's July 1863 and the Army of the Potomac is holding on. Yesterday the Johnnies hit hard and the line held. Today you are the leftmost flank of the army and must not give an inch of ground.
Though dulled by the morning mist, the shrill sound of a Rebel Yell is unmistakable. The Johnnies are on the move again.

Will you hold?

Rifles & Rebels is a unit based game where units are composed of 5 to 10 figures. In Rifles & Rebels you can choose from two sides and two arms with a total of four forces. You can be:

• Union Infantry
• Confederate Infantry
• Union Cavalry
• Confederate Cavalry
Whichever you choose you must lead one or more units of men through the war, the American Civil War, fighting when needed because it's all about victory and glory, and in some cases, just survival!
The cannon are booming, the troops mustering, and the fight is coming to you. Welcome to …

RIFLES & REBELS
Rifles & Rebels uses a floating scale which allows you to count each unit as a platoon, company, or battalion. This allows you to fight large battles as well as smaller actions.
Rifles & Rebels and Muskets & Mohawks share similar mechanics with changes made to reflect the different periods.

(From the producers website)

Priest of Apollo, Athena, Demeter, Poseidon or Zeus, 3-5 players try to make their worship the one who will dominate the whole of Greece. As you gather up YOur followers, build monumental temples, free the cities of mythological monsters, use your political weapons for your own benefit.

The game consists three phases:

     Action Phase
     Agora Phase
     Stage season


In his turn in first phase player places his followers to build temples, gather resources and hunt monsters to get more followers.

Also it is possible to convert opponents' cities, or even paralyze them by sending Your monsters to attack them.

In Agora Phase player deifies his heroes, who offer more improved actions for the action phase

Finally the season phase is a phase of replacement.

Player must meet at least 10 worshipers ( or have Three shrines before the end of the game to be the winner of the game.

German game celebrating Germany's fame, as they were once the leading airship manufacturer in the world.

The game is a simple roll and move game, taking your Zeppelin across Europe and visiting the major cities. Obey instructions if you land on special spaces. First to the end of the track, wins.

Undoubtedly seen as an educational game, teaching children about their neighbouring countries as well as their aeronautical history.

Take on the role of one of the Three Little Pigs as you try to build a house strong enough before the Big Bad Wolf arrives to blow it down and eat you.  Move around the board collecting straw, sticks, and/or bricks and then bring them back to your building site to build your house before the big bad wolf arrives.  Will you risk travelling further to get to the brick pile, or build a house of straw quickly and then sit back and relax counting on luck to save you when the big bad wolf comes calling.

Watch out, your brother pigs can steal what you’ve collected before you get it back to your house or speed up the wolf’s approach.  The pigs whose houses still stand at the end of the game are the winners.

Extra points are awarded for being lazy, but they only matter if your house can survive the coming wolf.

Do you want to take your chances by building a house of straw?

Do you have the time to gather the bricks for your house before the wolf arrives?

Are your brother pigs going to steal your bricks before you can get them back to your house?

Move fast and be smart or it won't matter how much hair you have on your chinny chin chin.

Game that tries to encourage people into the hobby of Genealogy, ancestor hunting you might say.

Generations is a board game with playing method which uses logic reasoning (in this regard, very similar to Cluedo) to solve a mystery of family history. Players search 7 regions of the United States for their make-believe ancestors, U.S. birthplaces, careers and lifestyles.

The first player to complete a family history (i.e. work out which facts are hidden, by eliminating facts that have been revealed to that player), wins.

Several game options ensure that play never becomes boring and that different levels of skill can be achieved. Variations include:
Logic Reasoning: Adapt for the time you have and the playing skill levels by varying the number of search categories. .
Storytelling: At the end of the game, the winner can make up a story about the discovered ancestor's life using "facts" found during play. This variation develops imagination and communication skills.
True Family History: Introduce players to real family stories as they "travel" regions of the United States asking questions about their pretend ancestors, where they were born, how they may have lived and how they earned their living.

Contents;
playing instructions (for home and classroom)
game board
moving pieces
dice
cards
lifestyle tokens
career tokens
ancestor worksheets
realistic family tree charts

Statistical tennis game, especially designed to get a result quickly, thus making it possible to play an event in one evening. Over 200 players are rated.

Various statistics are provided (ability, ranking, serving, etc.), and a die is used to get a specific result for an action you have just attempted.

Australian Chess variant played on a chequered board in the shape of a cross. Each side has 16 pieces but four pawns are larger than the other four. This designates them as either King's pawns or Queen's pawns. Bishops only play on black squares. Almost all other rules are standard chess rules and objectives.

Two games in one box, the only link being that they are both designed to help 7 to 11 year-olds with their maths.

Ski Race is a dice game with four special dice that have very unusual number spreads on them. Children are encouraged to do simple maths with the numbers rolled and thus advance in the Ski Race.

Go For Goal is a football related game for 2 players only. Each player has a hand of cards and must use them (with some simple mathematics) to move the ball around the pich.

The publisher is a major name when it comes to publishing books for budding Hi-Tech students.

"Goblin-Prügelparty" (Goblin-Beatingparty) is a Fantasy-cardgame in which two players take control of Goblins, kobolds and little devils, who enjoy beating up each other, after they have been summoned by a wizard who was not powerful enough to take control of them.
Players start with 3 cards on their hands and have to decide which cards to play for themselves and which to play for the opponent. Playing cards for the opponent may seem odd, but it is the only way to gain new cards. And since 11 cards in one of the card-rows end the game, you will need some more cards than the 3 you start with if you don't want the game to end early.
Nearly every single one of the 30 cards contains a unique effect, but while some of these effects are executed immediately, others wait for the end of the game before beeing executed. And you can't be completely sure whether they will be in the same position on the same side at that moment.
When the end is declared and the last effects have been executed, it is time to count the strenght and see who has collected the stronger - or more effective - little horde.

Players form two teams and each team chooses speaker.
The two speakers are placed side by side and they draws a card. There are words on the cards and speakers must explain it to players with the charades preferably more accessible to their own team.

The first team that sets the correct answer scores one point.

The game length is established before the game (10 points or 15 minutes). Winner is the team with the most points.

Game description from the publisher:

Conjudingo includes three easy, fun games to help students from Grade 1 to Grade 4 work on the present, future and past tenses of French verbs. The various animals on the cards will help you check if you have found the correct combination.

New version of the game Shabadabada but here are more about songs from movies that are played.

Shabadabada Cinoche is a game that caters specifically to cinema lovers who have a solid understanding of classic films.

Two teams compete using predetermined words.

As soon as a player sings part of a song which contains the current word, the other team must find another song containing the word. As soon as a team fails, the other one wins the card.

Add a colored tile each turn, trying to join the largest connected areas to maximize your score. Connect with all three colors for the most points. This game teaches pattern recognition and problem solving. With hundreds of combinations, there are infinite strategies to win!

Each turn, you connect one of your Game Tiles side to side to 1 or more Game Tiles in the middle of the table.  The colors of the just-placed tile must match all adjacent tiles.  Also, the corners of the Game Tiles must line up completely; that is to say that tiles may not overhang and the corners must match too.

Receive points for each game tile in the color chain that your tile connects to, but not including the tile you are adding.
This is a small trivia game belonging to the series Wissen-Spielen-Lernen. It contains 98 cards, with questions about the universe. When you answer the questions you can get plus or minus points.

The sleeping dragon is protecting her stash of golden eggs, and she won’t be pleased to wake and find there are lizards sharing space in her warm nest. Help the lizards escape without breaking any of her precious eggs. It takes a careful hand to remove the lizards!

In Dreaming Dragon, players use their fine motor skills to rescue the most lizards.

The Sleeping Dragon molded piece is placed in the center of the table, with 29 Lizards and 15 Golden Eggs placed on top of it.  On your turn, use your Pinchers to try to remove one of the Lizards from the dragon:

- If you are successful without anything falling off the dragon, place the Lizard in front of you. Well done! You also get to keep any other Lizards that are attached!
- If anything falls off the dragon, your turn ends immediately, but you can keep any Lizard already in your Pinchers (and any other Lizards attached to it).  Any Lizards that fall off are placed in the box, and any Golden Eggs that fall are placed in front of you!

When all Lizards are removed from the dragon, the game ends.  For each Golden Egg in front of you, you must return a Lizard!  After accounting for all Golden Eggs, the player with the most Lizards wins.

In City of Iron, 2-4 players compete to build up a small nation in a world of machines, magic, and money. Become the leader of one of four rival nations: the industrious humans, the toad engineers, the scholarly Cresarians, or the clever hogmen.  Produce goods like machine parts and bottled demons to gain wealth, or research steam-age technology and recruit mercenaries to control the continent. If you want to establish new cities, you’ll build schooners or airships to reach faraway lands and flying islands. Your cities have limited capacity, so you’ll have to decide what to keep and what to demolish when building advanced structures.  The future of a nation is in your hands. Build unbreakable foundations for an empire or disappear into the dusty pages of history.


    Build a civilization in a Steampunk setting
    Customize two decks of cards in a unique twist on deck-building
    Choose your path- build a powerful economy or conquer everything in sight
    Includes hundreds of lavishly-illustrated cards, an extra-large board, land boards, coin tokens, and more

Game description from the publisher:

Now fans can experience Wonderland in a way no one has ever experienced before as the comic book series Wonderland from Joe Brusha, Ralph Tedesco, and Raven Gregory comes to life in this exciting, strategy filled game. Experience a vibrant, twisted world, full of surprises! Players can choose to play as one of their favorite characters including Calie, the Mad Hatter, Brandon, the Queen of Hearts, the White Knight and a number of others.
 The board game Wonderland features two separate realms: Earth and Wonderland. The realms are artfully depicted on the double-sided board and switching between them adds a unique twist and an added level of complexity to the game that few other board games offer. Players compete against each other, each player trying to complete specific goals while the other players try to foil their attempts at progressing.

Game description from the publisher:

Guns of Galicia uses the same core rules as Guns of August (GoA) to simulate Corp-level fighting on the Eastern Front in WWI. Game mechanisms compensate for players' 20/20 hindsight to encourage historically accurate play that makes "sense" in game terms while avoiding a "straight jacket" of special rules to enforce irrational play. Players maneuver corps and divisions through 9-mile wide hexagons in turns that span three days each. Chit pull activation along with modest movement point allowances generates a highly interactive game. Scenarios included are the 1914 Galicia campaign, 1915 Tarnow campaign, and 1916 Brusilov campaign.

The Tweegles are monsters from another galaxy, come to invade the Earth. Unfortunately for them, once they hit the ground, nothing is on their scale. They are frightening and huge monsters on their own planet, but are only as big as mice on earth. They land in an everyday house, full of traps for them: electrical sockets, children with scissors and stamps, insects and cleaning products...

Twenty-five action cards – each showing a tweegle that has been hit by one of the "traps" – are laid face-up on the table at the start of Tweegles, while the twenty-five tweegle cards are shuffled and set aside. Everyone plays at the same time. One tweegle card is revealed from the deck, with the card showing one of five tweegle types and one of five possible actions, symbolized by scissors, a mosquito, an electrical socket, a stamp and spray bottle.

Everyone searches for the action card that "completes the story" begun with the first card. If a tweegle card shows scissors, for example, you need to find the cut-up tweegle among the face-up action cards. To claim the card, however, you need to perform the appropriate gesture: slapping the card if a mosquito is involved, hammering it with your fist if the tweegle was stamped, and so on. The first player to do this claims the tweegle card, while the action card remains on the table.

Whoever claims the most cards wins!

Players watch clips of wrestling matches from the old AWA league attempting to play a card that matches the move about to happen (there's a 3 second delay to allow players to choose which card to play)

A correct answer will allow that player to move his marker 2 spaces to the 'pin' space on the game board. If the card played has 'go for the pin', then if that player gets the next 2 card plays correct, they win. Game can also end when someone moves their marker to the pawn space

This small sized edition of Pictionary plays similar to the original, but the drawing is not timed as there is no timer included.  As wit traditional Picionary, players are drawing a picture based on a word from a card and trying to get their team-mates to guess the word in order to score points or advance.

User summary

A Japanese 2-player combat card game. Each player chooses two of nine witches, that all have their unique combination of spells, and take turns drawing cards from a deck consisting of 6 types of mana. Players build up their mana pools by playing "towers" (stacks) of cards from their hands, and can then activate these towers to unleash the spells of one or both of their witches.
Damage is represented by drawing cards from the mana deck; if two identical cards are drawn the pair dies.

Translated box blurb
When the stars align in the sky,
the witches prepare
for a battle of life and death

A promotional pack of cards, with the four normal suits being replaced by Bottles, Arks, Humphreys and Jokes.

The rules to various games are given:
Bottle Up!
Happy Humphreys (this is a slight variant of Happy Familes)
Hello Humphrey (better known as Pairs)
Humphrey Patience
Humphrey Overboard

There are 52 cards plus a Joker. Each suit bears a symbol to match its name, but the 13th card in each suit is always a crown. The game was mailed to interested customers in a plain white box except for one side that invites the owner to enter his or her name.

Each card also bears the normal traditional suit and number so that the cards could be used to any other card game that you like.

Trivia game about the nostalgic sixties. You can rediscover hippies, LSD, love beads and Vietnam. It is a simple trivia game that wasn't boxed.

According to an article in IN THESE TIMES SEPT 26-OCT 2. 1984, there is a board with a Peace Sign Layout that includes limbos like the Free Clinic or the Establishment or hell, a.k.a. Vietnam. It is very difficult to get out of Vietnam, the vertical bar in the peace-symbol shaped route. Most of the cards are Trivia cards, but some of them are "Karma Cards" which can send you to one of these limbos for several turns
There is a a Roll and Move component.

In Tokaido, each player is a traveler crossing the "East sea road", one of the most magnificent roads of Japan. While traveling, you will meet people, taste fine meals, collect beautiful items, discover great panoramas, and visit temples and wild places but at the end of the day, when everyone has arrived at the end of the road you'll have to be the most initiated traveler – which means that you'll have to be the one who discovered the most interesting and varied things.

The potential action spaces in Tokaido are laid out on a linear track, with players advancing down this track to take actions. The player who is currently last on the track takes a turn by advancing forward on the track to their desired action and taking that action, so players must choose whether to advance slowly in order to get more turns, or to travel more rapidly to beat other players to their desired action spaces.

The action spaces allow a variety of actions that will score in different, but roughly equal, ways. Some action spaces allow players to collect money, while others offer players a way to spend that money to acquire points.  Other action spaces allow players to engage in various set collections that score points for assembling those sets.  Some action spaces simply award players points for stopping on them, or give the player a randomly determined action from all of the other types.

All of the actions in Tokaido are very simple, and combined with a unique graphic design, Tokaido offers players a peaceful zen mood in its play.

The game consists of an "arena" (the game box with an insert) and lots of dice. The goal is to be the last player who still has dice. At the beginning, one die is in the arena. The active player throws another die into the arena. If both dice now show the same number, the player must take them out and end the turn. If not, the player can decide to throw in another die (possibly trying to overturn other dice) or end his/her turn. A die which shows the X face is removed from the game, as is any die which falls out of the arena. A player who holds no more dice is eliminated from the game. The last player who still has dice is the winner.

Sheepland is set on the beautiful island of the same name, where for centuries the population has taken care of sheep. While inexplicably working in the same field, two to four shepherds try to move sheep into the right areas to score points. During a turn, you must take three actions, chosen from these possibilities:
- Move your shepherd
- Move one sheep
- Buy one terrain tile

You must move your shepherd at least once during your turn, and you can't take the same action twice in a row without moving the shepherd in between the two actions.

Six different terrain types are available, with five tiles of each type and increasing costs (from 0 to 4 dinars). When you buy a tile, you're not claiming land on the game board, but rather investing in that type of landscape as that's where you expect the sheep to end up grazing. At the end of the game, you score 1 point per tile of a terrain type for each sheep in a region of this type; you also score for coins still in hand.

The map on the game board shows regions separated by roads: three regions of each terrain type for a total of 18 regions. Numbered "rest stops" lie along the roads, with each rest stop between exactly two regions. Shepherds move from one rest stop to another, with the first movement being free and all the others on the same turn costing 1 coin. When you buy a terrain, you can purchase the top tile of either of the two terrain types next to your shepherd. When you move a sheep, you move one sheep from a region adjacent to your shepherd to the other region adjacent to that piece, i.e., you lead the sheep across the road to a greener pasture – well, greener for you, if all goes well.

Each time you move the shepherd, you place a fence in the rest stop from which it started moving, making that location off-limits for the rest of the game. During the game some regions become inaccessible and, if they are full of sheep, a rush for the tiles takes place. The only black sheep in the game, which is worth two points, serves as a semi-random element, possibly moving to an adjacent region each turn while still being movable by shepherds as long as it's not fenced in.

After twenty fences have been placed, you end the round so that all players have the same number of turns, then you count up the points.

To learn the basics of poker fun there are 70 cards in 7 colors with numbers 1 to 10 in this game. Players bet with chips and collect different sets of 3 cards: best card, pair, row, three of a kind, color, three of a kind flash. Game lasts 10 rounds. Round lasts until the deck is exhausted. The player with the most chips is the winner.

You are the owner/coach/players of the football team.
Manage Your club well, choose stategy in each match and lead it to victory.

During the match roll 3 dice the ball on the total, and three players in the value of the three dice. During the management draw cards.

The owner of the best club at the end of the game is the winner.

Mix of Poker and Scrabble.
Player have card-tiles instead of letters with fifth additional suit and they place them on the gameboard scoring points with poker combinations. Of course there are bonus squares on the board what increase Your points.

Toss 'N' Roll Spooky Dice Math is a small-box game with a double-sided board and three glow-in-the dark orange dice.  The 16-page instruction manual includes directions for six simple math games, including Spider's Web, Big Numbers, Match Points, On the House, Shout Out and Prime Time.

Spider's Web: 
The dice are rolled onto a bull's eye board divided into eight pie sections labelled one through eight.  Depending on where the die landed, it is multiplied, added or subtracted from the number of the pie piece in which it landed.  No points are scored for dice which land in the exact center or off the board completely.  The winner is the first to reach a score of 300.

Big Numbers: 
Using the same board as Spider's Web, players roll the three dice onto the board, then scramble to be the first to find the largest three-digit number possible, using either the face value of the dice or the number slices into which they landed.  This game teaches place value and the winner is the first to reach 2,000.

Match Points: 
Each player rolls one die onto the spider web board, making a fraction with the smaller of the die or number slice value (on which the die landed) being the numerator.  When a player has collected enough fractions to be one or greater, he scores a point and starts over collecting fractions.  The first player to collect five whole numbers wins.

On the House:
Using the game board with six numbered houses, each player rolls one die onto the game board.  If the die matches any digit in the house square on which it landed, the player scores.  Scoring involves adding each of the digits of the three-digit number on the board together, then multiplying by the die value.  The winner is the first player to reach 250 points.

Shout Out:
A designated shooter rolls two dice off the board and one die onto the haunted house board.  Depending on which of the six house squares the die lands, all players race to perform the required math operations on the three dice first.  The first player to be the first ten times wins.

Prime Time:
Each player rolls the three dice onto the haunted house board, then looks for prime numbers amongst the sum of the die and door number, the dice themselves and the door numbers themselves.  Any missed primes may be stolen by other players.  The first player to reach 100 points is the winner.

The object of the game is to collect game pieces of his oppoenents.

In his turn player plays a card on the table to form vertical or horizontal combinations. He must places his game piece on it. To take away the opponent's pieces, you have to put a stronger combination.

Player with the most opponents's game pieces at the end of the game is the winner

Contents: Boardgame, heroes and challenge (monsters) cards, dice and 3 pawns.
Objective: to defeat and collect all 21 cards.

The boardgame consists of 3 interlocked circles. Playes move their pawns on the the circles. If you land on a space marked by the name of a character you can collect that character card. Other spaces are marked as combat spaces. Landing on a combat space allows you to challenge other players.

The battle takes place by presenting a number of character cards (battle force) and adding some points from the weapon circle according to the dice throw.

The winner of the battle takes all the cards that took part on the battle. When one player has managed to collect all the cards of the game is declared winner.

The object of the game is to score the most points by playing poker combinations on the table.

In his turn player places a card-tile on the table adjacent to any other tile. Player scores a points for all combinations the tile forms.

If the tile-deck is exhausted the player with the most points is the winner.

Promotional card game, made by the Irish company Lyons, who sell tea in Ireland and Great Britain.

Each player is dealt ten cards. The undealt cards are laid seperately in the centre of the table face down. The cards have either two letters or one letter on them and in one of four colours. In her turn, a player must choose one of the face down cards and then discard a card by returning a card from his hand by placing it face down in the centre of the table. However, before she does this, she must show it to all the other players. Now memory is added to the game because if you need a specific card, and you can remember that it was discarded earlier, it would be beneficial to recall where it is in the face down cards.

The object is to collect cards that spell out the words GREEN LABEL (the company's most famous brand). This could be as few as 5 cards (using double letter cards) or as many as 10 cards (using single letter cards). The first to do so, wins.

A party game, rare for this publisher. Indeed, it might be their only party game.

Three games are described in the rules - Forfeits, Double Forfeits and Charade Forfeits. They are all centred around the required player ability to perform some sort of action. The rules say that when one of their number has to do this, "the hilarity can well be imagined". Some cards are starred and if you draw one of these to perform, you can hand it to any other guest who now has to do the action. The games differ slightly in their winning conditions (the most successes, wins) except for the Charade variant where a team will win.

A game that will test your skills at mathematics.

Players draw tiles and put them on their rack. At the start of the timer, you try to form equations with your tiles (2x9=18, that sort of thing). You score points for the most tiles used before the timer runs out.

The most points when the game ends, wins.

Venture forth and do battle with your foes while trying not to contract the plague at the same time in this fast-paced trick taking card game. PLAGUE: The Card Game combines elements from classic trick-taking games like Spades and Black Maria and infuses rock-paper-scissors and a unique victory point scoring system that will have you both scratching your head and licking your lips.

The game takes place in a low-fantasy world much like Europe during the Dark Ages in which three major kingdoms are at war. These kingdoms are based loosely on real ones from that time period – but the war is the least of their concerns as a perilous and relentless plague is speading across the world. Now the kingdoms are being wiped out from all sides.

The players must protect their lands in battle to try to keep the plague at bay. You supply the bodies – let PLAGUE supply the fun!

From the box:

"The game where everyone is a target."

"Targets is a fast paced, easy to learn game. Play cards to build your hand, whittle down everyone else's, make temporary allies or retaliate against your foes. Remember, there can be only one winner. So target your friends, take their cards, block their actions and make sure, in the end, you are the only one holding cards."

Players are dealt 10 cards each to start. On each turn, a player may either play one card from their hand, or discard one card and draw a replacement. There are three types of cards: "Power" cards which stay in front of the player when played, "Quick Power" cards which can be played at any time, and "Action" cards that cause the action written on them to happen when played. The last player with cards in their hand is the winner.

There is no real theme to the game. The cards simply display text such as "Target misses their next turn", "Destroy target power card", and so on.
